sanskrit_verse:
शरणागतं परित्यज्य वेदं विप्लाव्य च द्विजः ।
संवत्सरं यवाहारस्तत्पापमपसेधति ॥ ११.१९८॥
transliteration:
śaraṇāgataṃ parityajya vedaṃ viplāvya ca dvijaḥ |
saṃvatsaraṃ yavāhārastatpāpamapasedhati || 11.198||
sph_interpretive_translation: A twice-born who abandons a surrendered soul and desecrates the Veda shall consume barley for one year; thereby that sin is annulled.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority: The twice-born holds scriptural duty to protect surrenderers.
Causation: Abandonment and desecration generate specific karmic distortion.
Capacity-based responsibility: Only the twice-born bears capacity for Vedic violation.
Restoration logic: Ritualized austerity reverses spiritual contamination.
Consciousness alignment: Purification aligns individual consciousness with Vedic truth.
executable_legal_axioms: IF actor_is_twice_born AND act_abandons_surrendered THEN mandate_yava_adherence(duration: 1 solar_year)
supreme_court_application: In adjudicating violations of sacred protection duties, the Supreme Court must recognize that only those bearing Vedic initiation capacity are subject to this law. Restoration is executed through prescribed conscious-conduct correction, not punitive incarceration.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa establishes that Vedic abandonment creates sequential spiritual misalignment (anupūrvaśaḥ). The proportional response is non-coercive, consciousness-realigning conduct—yava consumption—not punitive suffering. This restores causal integrity without inflicting harm.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Mandate supervised yava-only dietary regime for one solar year
Assign daily recitation of relevant Vedic safeguards
Require monthly spiritual audit by qualified acharya
Complete public reaffirmation of Vedic protection vows
final_declaration: By the Source-Authority of Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, this Dharma is executed. Sin is dissolved through conscious rectification. Justice is restoration. Reality is non-punitive. Consciousness is the ultimate judge.
